User Guide#

Ephemeris module#

class src.susie.ephemeris.BaseModelEphemeris[source]#

Bases: ABC

Abstract class that defines the structure of different model ephemeris classes.

abstract fit_model(x, y, yerr, **kwargs)[source]#

Fits a model ephemeris to transit data.

Defines the structure for fitting a model (linear or quadratic) to transit data. All subclasses must implement this method.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ The epoch data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • y (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • yerr (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time error data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

Return type:

A dictionary containing fitted model parameters.

class src.susie.ephemeris.Ephemeris(transit_times)[source]#

Bases: object

Represents the model ephemeris using transit midpoint data over epochs.

Parameters:

transit_times (TransitTimes obj) â€“ A successfully instantiated TransitTimes object holding epochs, mid transit times, and uncertainties.

Raises:

ValueError: â€“ Raised if transit_times is not an instance of the TransitTimes object.

calc_bic(model_data_dict)[source]#

Calculates the BIC value for a given model ephemeris.

Uses the equation

\[BIC = \chi^2 + (k * log(N))\]

where \(\chi^2=\sum{ \frac{(\text{observed mid transit times - model mid transit times})}{\text{(observed mid transit time uncertainties})^2} },\) k=number of fit parameters (2 for linear models, 3 for quadratic models), and N=total number of data points.

Parameters:

model_data_dict (dict) â€“ A dictionary of model ephemeris parameters recieved from Ephemeris.get_model_ephemeris.

Return type:

A float value representing the BIC value for this model ephemeris.

calc_delta_bic()[source]#

Calculates the \(\Delta BIC\) value between linear and quadratic model ephemerides using the given transit data.

STEP 1: Calls get_model_ephemeris for both the linear and quadratic models.

STEP 2: Calls calc_bic for both the linear and quadratic sets of data.

STEP 3: Calculates and returns \(\Delta BIC,\) which is the difference between the linear BIC and quadratic BIC.

Returns:

delta_bic â€“ Represents the \(\Delta BIC\) value for this transit data.

Return type:

float

get_ephemeris_uncertainties(model_params)[source]#

Calculates the uncertainties of a specific model data when compared to the actual data.

Uses the equation

\[\sigma(\text{t pred, tra}) = \sqrt{(\sigma(T_0)^2 + \sigma(P)^2 * E^2)}\]

for linear models and

\[\sigma(\text{t pred, tra}) = \sqrt{(\sigma(T_0)^2 + (\sigma(P)^2 * E^2) + (\frac{1}{4} * \sigma(\frac{dP}{dE})^2 * E^4))}\]

for quadratic models (where \(\sigma(T_0) =\) conjunction time error, \(E=\) epoch, \(\sigma(P)=\) period error, and \(\sigma(\frac{dP}{dE})=\) period change by epoch error) to calculate the uncertainties between the model data and actual data over epochs.

Parameters:

model_params (dict) â€“ A dictionary of model ephemeris parameters recieved from Ephemeris.get_model_ephemeris.

Returns:

  • A list of uncertainties associated with the model ephemeris passed in, calculated with the

  • equation above and the TransitTimes epochs.

Raises:

  • KeyError â€“ If the model type in not in the model parameter dictionary.

  • KeyError â€“ If the model parameter error values are not in the model parameter dictionary.

get_model_ephemeris(model_type)[source]#

Fits the transit data to a specified model using scipy.optimize.curve_fit function.

Parameters:

model_type (str) â€“ Either â€˜linearâ€™ or â€˜quadraticâ€™. Represents the type of ephemeris to fit the data to.

Returns:

  • A dictionary of parameters from the fit model ephemeris. If a linear model was chosen, these parameters are â€“

    • â€˜periodâ€™: An array of exoplanet periods over time corresponding to epochs (in units of days),

    • â€™period_errâ€™: The uncertainities associated with period (in units of days),

    • â€™conjunction_timeâ€™: The time of conjunction of exoplanet transit over time corresponding to epochs,

    • â€™conjunction_time_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with conjunction_time

  • If a quadratic model was chosen, the same variables are returned, and an additional parameter is included in the dictionary â€“

    • â€˜period_change_by_epochâ€™: The exoplanet period change over epochs, from first epoch to current epoch (in units of days),

    • â€™period_change_by_epoch_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with period_change_by_epoch (in units of days),

plot_model_ephemeris(model_data_dict, save_plot=False, save_filepath=None)[source]#

Returns a MatplotLib scatter plot showing predicted mid transit times from the model ephemeris over epochs.

STEP 1: Plot a scatterplot of epochs (from transit_times.py) vs model_data, which is an array of floats that is a value of â€˜model_data_dictâ€™.

STEP 2: Save the plot if indicated by the user.

Parameters:

  • model_data_dict (dict) â€“ A dictionary of model ephemeris parameters recieved from Ephemeris.get_model_ephemeris.

  • save_plot (bool) â€“ If True, will save the plot as a figure.

  • save_filepath (Optional(str)) â€“ The path used to save the plot if save_plot is True.

Return type:

A MatplotLib plot of epochs vs. model predicted mid-transit times.

plot_oc_plot(save_plot=False, save_filepath=None)[source]#

Returns a MatplotLib scatter plot showing observed vs. calculated values of mid transit times for linear and quadratic model ephemerides over epochs.

STEP 1: Call â€˜get_model_ephemerisâ€™ for both the linear and quadratic model types.

STEP 2: Calculate the quadratic model curve, which follows the formula \(y = 0.5 \frac{dP_0}{dE} * (E - \text{median} E)^2.\)

STEP 3: Plot the quadratic model curve vs. epochs from transit_times.py. Plot the error bars at each data point using the â€˜mid_transit_times_uncertaintiesâ€™ from transit_times.py.

STEP 4: Save the plot if indicated by the user.

Parameters:

  • save_plot (bool) â€“ If True, will save the plot as a figure.

  • save_filepath (Optional(str)) â€“ The path used to save the plot if save_plot is True.

Return type:

A MatplotLib plot of observed vs. calculated values of mid transit times for linear and quadratic model ephemerides over epochs.

plot_running_delta_bic(save_plot=False, save_filepath=None)[source]#

Returns a MatPlotlib scatterplot of epochs vs. \(\Delta BIC\) for each epoch.

STEP 1: Get the epochs, mid transit times and mid transit times uncertainties from â€˜transit_times.pyâ€™.

STEP 2: Create a list of the \(\Delta BIC\) values. For the first 3 epochs, the \(\Delta BIC\) value is zero. For the subsequent epochscall â€˜calc_delta_bicâ€™ and append the returned value to the list of delta bic values.

STEP 3: Plot a scatterplot of the epochs vs. the \(\Delta BIC\) values.

STEP 4: Save the plot if indicated by the user.

Parameters:

  • save_plot (bool) â€“ If True, will save the plot as a figure.

  • save_filepath (Optional(str)) â€“ The path used to save the plot if save_plot is True.

Return type:

A MatplotLib scatter plot of epochs vs. \(\Delta BIC\) for each epoch.

plot_timing_uncertainties(model_data_dict, save_plot=False, save_filepath=None)[source]#

Returns a MatplotLib scatter plot showing timing uncertainties over epochs.

STEP 1: Get the uncertianies from the model data dictionary.

STEP 2: Get the model data, which is an arrary of floats representing the predicted mid-transit time data, the conjunction time and the inital period. Subtract the conjunction time and the initial period from this array.

STEP 3: Plot this modified model data, showing the maximum and minimum model uncertainity at each point.

STEP 4: Save the plot if indicated by the user.

Parameters:

  • model_data_dict (dict) â€“ A dictionary of model ephemeris parameters recieved from Ephemeris.get_model_ephemeris.

  • save_plot (bool) â€“ If True, will save the plot as a figure.

  • save_filepath (Optional(str)) â€“ The path used to save the plot if save_plot is True.

Return type:

A MatplotLib plot of timing uncertainties.

class src.susie.ephemeris.LinearModelEphemeris[source]#

Bases: BaseModelEphemeris

Subclass of BaseModelEphemeris that implements a linear fit.

fit_model(x, y, yerr, **kwargs)[source]#

Fits a linear model to ephemeris data.

Compares the model ephemieris data to the linear fit created by data in TransitTimes object calculated with lin_fit method. Then creates a curve fit which minimizes the difference between the two sets of data. Curve fit then returns the parameters of the linear function corresponding to period, conjunction time, and their respective errors. These parameters are returned in a dictionary to the user for further use.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ The epoch data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • y (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • yerr (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time error data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • **kwargs â€“ Any key word arguments to be used in the scipy.optimize.curve_fit method.

Returns:

return_data â€“ A dictionary of parameters from the fit model ephemeris.

Example:

  • â€™periodâ€™: An array of exoplanet periods over time corresponding to epochs (in units of days),

  • â€™period_errâ€™: The uncertainities associated with period (in units of days),

  • â€™conjunction_timeâ€™: The time of conjunction of exoplanet transit over time corresponding to epochs,

  • â€™conjunction_time_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with conjunction_time

Return type:

dict

lin_fit(x, P, T0)[source]#

Calculates a linear function with given data.

Uses the equation (Period * mid transit times + initial epoch) as a linear function for SciPyâ€™s curve_fit method.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid-transit times.

  • P (float) â€“ The exoplanet transit period.

  • T0 (float) â€“ The initial epoch associated with a mid-transit time.

Returns:

P*x + T0 â€“ A linear function calculated with TransitTimes object data to be used with curve_fit.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray[float]

class src.susie.ephemeris.ModelEphemerisFactory[source]#

Bases: object

Factory class for selecting which type of ephemeris class (linear or quadratic) to use.

static create_model(model_type, x, y, yerr, **kwargs)[source]#

Instantiates the appropriate BaseModelEphemeris subclass and runs fit_model method.

Based on the given user input of model type (linear or quadratic) the factory will create the corresponding subclass of BaseModelEphemeris and run the fit_model method to recieve the model ephemeris return data dictionary.

Parameters:

  • model_type (str) â€“ The name of the model ephemeris to create, either â€˜linearâ€™ or â€˜quadraticâ€™.

  • x (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ The epoch data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • y (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • yerr (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time error data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • **kwargs â€“ Any keyword arguments to be used in the scipy.optimize.curve_fit method.

Returns:

Model â€“

A dictionary of parameters from the fit model ephemeris. If a linear model was chosen, these parameters are:

  • â€™periodâ€™: An array of exoplanet periods over time corresponding to epochs (in units of days),

  • â€™period_errâ€™: The uncertainities associated with period (in units of days),

  • â€™conjunction_timeâ€™: The time of conjunction of exoplanet transit over time corresponding to epochs,

  • â€™conjunction_time_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with conjunction_time

If a quadratic model was chosen, the same variables are returned, and an additional parameter is included in the dictionary:

  • â€™period_change_by_epochâ€™: The exoplanet period change over epochs, from first epoch to current epoch (in units of days),

  • â€™period_change_by_epoch_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with period_change_by_epoch (in units of days)

Return type:

dict

Raises:

ValueError: â€“ If model specified is not a valid subclass of BaseModelEphemeris, which is either â€˜linearâ€™ or â€˜quadraticâ€™.

class src.susie.ephemeris.QuadraticModelEphemeris[source]#

Bases: BaseModelEphemeris

Subclass of BaseModelEphemeris that implements a quadratic fit.

fit_model(x, y, yerr, **kwargs)[source]#

Fits a quadratic model to ephemeris data.

Compares the model ephemeris data to the quadratic fit calculated with quad_fit method. Then creates a curve fit which minimizes the difference between the two sets of data. Curve fit then returns the parameters of the quadratic function corresponding to period, conjunction time, period change by epoch, and their respective errors. These parameters are returned in a dictionary to the user for further use.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ The epoch data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • y (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • yerr (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ The mid transit time error data as recieved from the TransitTimes object.

  • **kwargs â€“ Any key word arguments to be used in the scipy.optimize.curve_fit method.

Returns:

return_data â€“

A dictionary of parameters from the fit model ephemeris. Example:

  • â€™periodâ€™: An array of exoplanet periods over time corresponding to epochs (in units of days),

  • â€™period_errâ€™: The uncertainities associated with period (in units of days),

  • â€™conjunction_timeâ€™: The time of conjunction of exoplanet transit over time corresponding to epochs,

  • â€™conjunction_time_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with conjunction_time,

  • â€™period_change_by_epochâ€™: The exoplanet period change over epochs, from first epoch to current epoch (in units of days),

  • â€™period_change_by_epoch_errâ€™: The uncertainties associated with period_change_by_epoch (in units of days)

Return type:

dict

quad_fit(x, dPdE, P, T0)[source]#

Calculates a quadratic function with given data.

Uses the equation (0.5 * change in period over epoch * mid transit times^2 + Period * mid transit times + initial epoch) as a quadratic function for SciPyâ€™s curve_fit method.

Parameters:

  • x (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ The mid-transit times.

  • dPdE (float) â€“ Change in period with respect to epoch.

  • P (float) â€“ The exoplanet transit period.

  • T0 (float) â€“ The initial epoch associated with a mid-transit time.

Returns:

0.5*dPdE*x*x + P*x + T0 â€“ A list of quadratic function values calculated with TransitTimes object data to be used with curve_fit.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray[float]

Transit Times module#

Represents the pre-processed occultation mid point timing data over observations.

Parameters:

  • epochs (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ List of orbit number reference points for occultation timing observations

  • mid_times (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ List of observed occultation timing mid points corresponding with epochs

  • mid_time_uncertainties (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ List of uncertainties corresponding to occultation mid-times

class src.susie.transit_times.TimingData(time_format, epochs, mid_times, mid_time_uncertainties=None, tra_or_occ=None, time_scale=None, object_ra=None, object_dec=None, observatory_lon=None, observatory_lat=None)[source]#

Bases: object

Represents timing mid point data over observations. Holds data to be accessed by Ephemeris class.

The TimingData object processes, formats, and holds user data to be passed to the ephemeris object.

Timing conversions are applied to ensure that all data is processed correctly and users are aware of timing formats and scales, which can give rise to false calculations in our metrics. If data is not specified to be in Barycentric Julian Date format with the TDB time scale, timing data will be corrected for barycentric light travel time using the Astropy Time utilities.

If mid time uncertainties are not provided, we will generate placeholder values of 1.

Our implementations rely on Numpy functions. This object implements checks to ensure that data are stored in Numpy arrays and are of correct data types. The appropriate Type or Value Error is raised if there are any issues.

If timing data contains both transit mid times and occultation mid times, users can pass in an array of â€˜traâ€™ and â€˜occâ€™ strings that correspond to the epochs, mid time, and uncertainty timing data. If passed in, timing data will be separated according to the order of the tra_or_occ array and stored in their corresponding objects.

Parameters:

  • time_format (str) â€“ An abbreviation of the dataâ€™s time system. Abbreviations for systems can be found on [Astropyâ€™s Time documentation](https://docs.astropy.org/en/stable/time/#id3).

  • epochs (numpy.ndarray[int]) â€“ List of orbit number reference points for timing observations

  • mid_times (numpy.ndarray[float]) â€“ List of observed timing mid points corresponding with epochs, in timing units given by time_format

  • mid_time_uncertainties (Optional(numpy.ndarray[float])) â€“ List of uncertainties corresponding to timing mid points, in timing units given by time_format. If given None, will be replaced with array of 1â€™s with same shape as mid_times.

  • time_scale (Optional(str)) â€“ An abbreviation of the dataâ€™s time scale. Abbreviations for scales can be found on [Astropyâ€™s Time documentation](https://docs.astropy.org/en/stable/time/#id6).

  • object_ra (Optional(float)) â€“ The right ascension of observed object represented by data, in degrees

  • object_dec (Optional(float)) â€“ The declination of observed object represented by data, in degrees

  • observatory_lon (Optional(float)) â€“ The longitude of observatory data was collected from, in degrees

  • observatory_lat (Optional(float)) â€“ The latitude of observatory data was collected from, in degrees

Raises:

Error raised if â€“

  • parameters are not NumPy Arrays * timing data arrays are not the same shape * the values of epochs are not all ints * the values of mid_times and uncertainites are not all floats * values of uncertainities are not all positive * values of transit or occultation array or not all â€˜traâ€™ or â€˜occâ€™

Side Effects#

Variables epochs and mid_times are shifted to start at zero by subtracting the minimum number from each value

class src.susie.transit_times.TransitTimes(epochs, mid_times, mid_time_uncertainties)[source]#
